channel.title: Posts on Pharmacy AI Newsletter
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Pharmacy AI Newsletter

item.title: Predicting Delayed Clearance in Pediatric High-Dose Methotrexate
item.description: In 1,485 pediatric high-dose methotrexate cycles, a machine learning model predicted delayed excretion with strong discrimination; XGBoost performed best (AUROC 0.842) and high specificity. An eight-variable model—driven most by serum creatinine and total dose—was released as a web tool for pre-cycle risk stratification to guide supportive care intensity.

item.title: Practical Framework for Deploying Radiology AI Tools
item.description: A governance-focused playbook outlines four phases—local validation, stepwise deployment, value measurement, and ongoing surveillance—to move radiology AI from promising models to sustained clinical services. It prioritizes workflow fit, return on investment beyond accuracy metrics, and continuous drift monitoring to decide if tools work, help, and stay.

item.title: Protocol: AI EHR Nudge to Prevent Hospital-Acquired Venous Thromboembolism
item.description: This pragmatic randomized trial will test an artificial intelligence–driven electronic health record nudge that prompts VTE prophylaxis for hospitalized adults at high predicted risk without an active order or documented contraindications. Conducted across urban and rural hospitals, it will compare the AI CDS to standard workflows on hospital-acquired VTE incidence, safety (bleeding), and process outcomes.

item.title: Minimal transcriptomic panels predict Pseudomonas antibiotic resistance
item.description: From RNA-seq of 414 Pseudomonas aeruginosa isolates, 35–40-gene expression panels predicted resistance to meropenem, ciprofloxacin, tobramycin, and ceftazidime with 96–99% test accuracy (F1 0.93–0.99). The compact, largely non-overlapping signatures relied mostly on genes outside current resistance databases, pointing to viable diagnostic panels but needing external validation before clinical use.

item.title: Limits of Inter-Hospital Model Transfer in Delirium Detection
item.description: A multi-institution study deployed an open-source NLP model to detect delirium features from EHR notes, achieving feasible but variable performance across seven health systems. The project established a shared ontology, temporal conventions, and site-specific preprocessing to improve portability and consistency.

item.title: LLMs show partial utility for DDI checks
item.description: This review finds that LLMs can detect many common drug–drug interactions with clear explanations, but they miss uncommon ones, vary in severity ratings, and sometimes hallucinate contraindications.

item.title: Rule-Based CDS: A Literature Review of Impact and Evolution
item.description: This scoping review of 28 studies (2007–2023) maps how rule-based CDSS are used across medicine, highlighting both measurable gains and persistent barriers.

item.title: Six-lab causal AI for early AKI detection post cardiac surgery
item.description: A causal AI model (REACT) predicts cardiac surgery-associated acute kidney injury up to 48 hours earlier than guidelines using six routine lab values.

item.title: External Validation and Bias in Opioid Risk Prediction Models
item.description: A study evaluating an opioid risk prediction model found that external population shifts reduced performance and fairness, requiring local recalibration and subgroup-specific threshold tuning for equitable clinical use.

item.title: Machine learning to guide infant voriconazole dosing
item.description: A study combining population pharmacokinetics and machine learning to predict voriconazole exposure in immunocompromised infants under 24 months.

item.title: Deep Learning Model for the Prediction of Vancomycin Trough Concentration
item.description: Evaluation of Nephrocast-V, a sequential deep learning model predicting vancomycin trough concentrations in ICU patients, benchmarked against pharmacist-driven Bayesian dosing.

item.title: Evaluation of Explainable AI Frameworks in Healthcare
item.description: Evaluation of multiple explainable AI methods (local and global) in healthcare using the XAI-Eval framework to assess fidelity, stability, complexity, and trustworthiness of clinical predictions.

item.title: LLM-Based Clinical Decision Support for Medication Safety
item.description: A comprehensive analysis of how large language models can enhance medication safety through clinical decision support systems across 16 medical specialties.

item.title: MiADE: NLP at the Point of Care
item.description: This study evaluates MiADE, an open-source NLP system integrated into Epic to convert clinical notes into structured data, aiming to improve documentation completeness and reduce clinician burden.

item.title: Cancer Diagnosis Categorization with LLMs and BioBERT
item.description: This JMIR Cancer 2025 study evaluated GPT-3.5, GPT-4o, Llama 3.2, Gemini 1.5, and BioBERT for categorizing oncology diagnoses from structured ICD-10 codes and free-text EHR notes into 14 categories, highlighting both potential and risks of LLM-based structuring of clinical data.

item.title: Journal Club Summary: AI-Guided Dosing Decisions (Sumner et al., 2025)
item.description: Healthcare providers’ perspectives on AI-guided dosing, including perceived benefits, barriers, and implications for pharmacy informatics.
